JAMAICA For and About Creatures On the Earth's Edge

''You've been living on the edge all your life, the boundary between land and air,'' according to the University of Rhode Island's Office of Marine Programs. ''Living on the Edge: An Interactive Coastal Exhibit'' is a traveling exhibition that was developed by that office and the Museum of Science in Boston.
The exhibit, which is now visiting the Queens Library Gallery, and will be on view through Aug. 26, is a celebration of the coastline where the land meets the sea.

The main exhibit is supplemented by science storytelling on Tuesdays at 3 p.m. and science experiments and crafts on Thursdays at 3 p.m. A display of lobsters, crabs and their kin is presented by the wildlife Conservation Society and video teleconferencing programs with the Ocean Institute of Dana Point, Calif.

''Living on the Edge: An Interactive Coastal Exhibit'' through Aug. 26, daily hours Monday through Friday, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m., Saturday 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Queens Borough Public Library Gallery and Auditorium, 89-11 Merrick Boulevard, Jamaica; free; (718) 990-8665.
UPPER WEST SIDE Stars of Jazz and Sky Vie for Attention at Hayden
Jazz stars are coexisting with galactic ones at ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere'' under the Hayden Sphere at the new Rose Center for Earth and Space.

This Friday and Aug. 25, there will be performances of live Afro-Cuban jazz by Bobby Sanabria and his band, Quinteto Ache. Table seating is available on a first-come-first-served basis, and there is a cash bar with tapas-style food and alcoholic and nonalcoholic drinks. (One of the season's earlier Friday night events is shown below.)

Children are welcome, to dance the night away and busy themselves with the hands-on exhibits that surround the staging area. The museum itself stays open until 8:45 on ''Starry Nights,'' and visitors can buy tickets to the space show, ''Passport to the Universe,'' which is narrated by Tom Hanks.
These stellar evenings will continue on Friday nights through the fall with a changing lineup.

''Starry Nights'' Friday, 5:45 p.m. to 8:15 p.m.; Rose Center for Earth and Space at the American Museum of Natural History, West 81st Street off Central Park West; suggested donation $10; children 2 through 12 $6; students and people over 65, $7.50; (212) 769-5100.
UPPER EAST SIDE Marathon Menschen At Israeli Folk Dancing

Beginner and experienced dancers of a wide range of ages gather on Wednesday evenings for four or five hours of dancing and mingling at the 92nd Street Y's Israeli folk dance sessions. And this Saturday, the Y plans to make it a marathon, with dancing anticipated to go until 1 a.m.

The sessions feature oldies and new favorites, and dances for couples and circle dancing are taught by Ruth Goodman and Danny Uziel, who have both been with 92d Street Y for years. (Some paricipants earlier this year are pictured below.)
The summer schedule, through Sept. 27, has Wednesday night open sessions with some informal instruction at the beginning of the session. Advance registration is not required.

Israeli Folk Dance, Wednesday, open session 8:30 p.m.; Buttenwieser Hall, 92nd Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue at 92nd Street; $9; Summer Marathon, Saturday 8:45 p.m.; at the 92nd Street Y; $10; (212) 415-5737.
ALSO AROUND TOWN

THE LIVING IS GROOVY -- ''Sweet Summer Grooves'' features Chico DeBarge as part of the Martin Luther King Jr. Concert Series presented by State Senator Marty Markowitz; tomorrow 8 p.m.; Wingate Field, Winthrop Street, near Kingston Avenue in Brooklyn, behind Wingate High School; free; (718) 469-1912.

VINTAGE SOUNDS -- Peggy Cone and the Central Park Stompers will perform hits from the 30's, 40's and 50's, complete with vintage fashions; Wednesday 6:30 p.m. (rain date Thursday); at 6 p.m., Ms. Cone will show the audience a few dance steps; Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale, 5901 Palisade Avenue, at 261st Street; free; (718) 581-1111.

WHERE NEON LIGHTS ARE BRIGHT -- Municipal Art Society's tour series, ''Discover New York,'' marches on today with ''On Broadway: Herald Square and Times Square in Transition,'' in conjunction with the exhibit ''American Modern, 1925-1940: Design for a New Age'' at Metropolitan Museum of Art; tour includes Empire State Building, office buildings, garment district lofts, banks and theaters; today 1 p.m.; meet at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 34th Street; $15; members $12; (212) 935-3960.
